thread.title: CMA Rules Out Ending Free-In-Credit Banking

title: CMA Rules Out Ending Free-In-Credit Banking
text:
View Photo 

Bank current account customers could save an average of £70 annually by switching providers, regulators will say on Thursday as they rule out radical structural changes to the industry. 
Sky News can reveal that the Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has concluded that Britain's free-if-in-credit current accounts model should not be abolished, because there "is no evidence that it distorts competition", according to a person familiar with the report. 
The regulator will also say that broader structural remedies such as breaking up big banks or forcing them to sell branches would not address the concerns identified by its inquiry team. 
Those conclusions will come despite the CMA's admission that banks do not have to work hard enough to compete for customers, and that they are not put under enough competitive pressure, even with the advent of a number of digital-only rivals. 
The CMA will outline a series of potential measures aimed at bolstering competition in the £16bn market, including the creation of a price comparison website for small business customers, and a requirement for banks to prompt customers to explore switching to alternative providers if their branch closes or their teaser rate comes to an end. 
The CMA's preliminary report will come after 18 months of investigation, and exhortations from challenger banks to recommend radical options such as forcing banks to charge customers for current accounts. 
Bank executives such as Virgin Money chief executive Jayne-Anne Gadhia have argued that the existing model distorts the market and creates a bias towards the biggest players. 
More than 75% of current accounts are supplied by Barclays (LSE: BARC.L - news ) , HSBC, Lloyds Banking Group (Other OTC: LLOBF - news ) and Royal Bank of Scotland (LSE: RBS.L - news ) , while in small business (SME) banking, that figure is even higher, at 85%. 
Despite those figures, the CMA will say that while the banking market is concentrated, it is not "highly concentrated", a source said. 
Controversially, it will also declare that Lloyds' emergency rescue of HBOS during the 2008 banking crisis did not diminish competition in the UK market. 
Sources said on Wednesday that the regulator's report would outline a number of important conclusions, including the fact that heavy overdraft users could save an average of £260-a-year by switching current account providers, while all customers could save an average of £70 by doing so. 
The potential remedies to be announced by the CMA include an upgrading of a Government-backed tool called Midata, which helps users to compare current account providers by uploading their banking history to a website. 
The CMA is expected to say that such a change, allowing users to compare accounts at the touch of a button, could have "a radical impact on consumer choice". 
Watchdogs want that to be made easier to use, as well as a big investment in a campaign to promote awareness of the seven-day current account switching service. 
Launched two years ago, its performance has been lauded by ministers, but only 2% of current account customers have used it, and just 16% of consumers examined switching to alternative providers last year. 
Better sharing of data with credit rating agencies will also be among the recommendations, a source said. 
The issue of customer engagement is particularly acute in the SME market, with the CMA expected to say that more than half of small business start-ups use the same bank as they do for their personal current account. 
Following complaints from smaller banks about George Osborne's decision to impose a new surcharge on bank profits, the CMA will say it is "too early" to assess the measure's impact on competition. 
A final report, expected next year, will address that question in more detail. 
The CMA declined to comment on Wednesday night.
